awd_titl_txt: The Downside of Smelling for Danger: Fitness Costs of Plant Defense Priming via Plant-Plant Volatile Signaling
awd_abstract_narration:
Plants can detect airborne chemicals in their environment that are indicative of impending stress and prepare defenses prior to experiencing the stress. This phenomenon has been termed "priming". This project explores the molecular patterns of response indicative of priming using both field observations and controlled environment experiments. Since ecological theory predicts that there should be a cost to priming, measurements of the effects of priming on plant growth, reproduction and rates of herbivory will be used to determine both the costs and benefits of priming. Finally, the progeny of primed and non-primed plants will be examined to determine if the offspring of primed plants are better defended than offspring from non-primed plants. This project will continue the "Million Leaf Project", which is a science workshop developed by the lead investigator to introduce citizens and grade school students to plant-insect interactions by teaching an experiential approach to both measure and analyze the damage experienced by plants and their leaves. Participants collect their own data to explore how much pressure insect consumers put on plants, and therefore how plant chemical defenses and sensory perception might have evolved. The results of this research may also be applied to inducing greater resistance to herbivory in agricultural crops, thereby reducing losses to pests.

The principle objective of this study is to test fitness costs and molecular patterns associated with defense priming under controlled and field conditions in two phylogenetically disparate Rosids: Arabidopsis thaliana and Phaseolus lunatus.  Overwhelming evidence exists that plants respond to certain volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as herbivore-induced plant volatiles (HIPVs) from their neighbors or distal parts of themselves by "priming" (i.e., preparing) their defenses. However, the volatile-associated molecular patterns (VAMPs) indicative of priming are not well known. Moreover, ecological theory predicts that induced processes should incur fitness costs, but there is currently limited evidence to support this prediction with respect to HIPV-mediated priming. The project will test the hypothesis that plants responding to HIPVs will incur measurable fitness costs that will be less severe than costs of induced resistance, and that HIPV-primed plants will produce offspring with altered physiology indicative of priming (i.e., they will be "Primed to be Primed"). This project will address a key gap in our understanding of defense priming. The project includes post-doctoral, graduate and undergraduate training. Undergraduates will be required from a diverse population of historically underrepresented groups at the University of Louisville.  Citizen science outreach is included through the "Million Leaf Project" where participants learn to quantify herbivore damage to leaves and develop their own hypotheses related to the ecology and evolution of plant-herbivore interactions.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this grant was to investigate fitness consequences on plants and their offspring responding to volatile stress cues. Additionally, this grant explored gene expression patterns in plants exposed to these cues.

Intellectual Merit: Plants typically emit bouquets of volatile compounds when attacked by insect herbivores. These volatiles attract natural enemies and can be noxious to herbivores, but neighboring plants can also detect and respond to these airborne cues. Plants receiving volatile cues can "prime" (or prepare) their defenses in advance of an actual threat. Priming, by definition, is a process that is deployed only when a cue is detected, which makes priming an "induced" process. Ecological theory predicts that induced processes should incur fitness costs, but this had not been tested for volatile-mediated priming.  This project aimed to address this key knowledge gap.

We first conducted field experiments with Lima Bean (Phaseolus lunatus) and Chile Pepper (Capsicum annuum) to manipulate the duration and timing of a volatile stress cue. We used a single volatile compound, cis-3-hexenyl acetate ("z3HAC"), which is a "green leaf volatile" and a component of freshly mowed grass that I'd previously shown to be a priming cue. To deliver targeted doses and isolate effects of the volatile, we made "dispensers" of the volatile and placed these adjacent to individual plants. Interestingly, priming was observed as a short-term phenomenon that had no effect on plant fitness overall, whereas long-term experimental application of the volatile cue noticeably altered growth, defense, and reproductive fitness. These results indicate that plants grown in nature engage priming over short time periods and yet are flexible enough to avoid measurable fitness costs of those short-term responses. The results also established the potential commercial applications of using dispensers loaded with chemical cues to enhance plant productivity.

We then asked whether ungerminated plant seeds could be primed. We applied volatile cues directly to ungerminated seeds of Thale Cress (Arabidopsis thaliana). Interestingly, plants grown from seeds receiving either of two specific cues (z3HAC and indole) were better defended against herbivores relative to those without these cues. This enhanced defense was even detectable in the offspring of plants grown from volatile-treated seeds. Moreover, we saw similar results when we repeated the experiment using Barrel Medic (Medicago truncatula). As these species are not related, our results suggest that seed priming is a common and important ecological phenomenon.

Next, we used Thale Cress to explore molecular and chemical patterns of priming in primed plants and their offspring. We used the same volatile cue and subjected primed plants to two different species of insect herbivores: the beet armyworm and the cabbage looper. We measured gene expression using RNA sequencing and found that expression patterns of leaf priming were unique to each herbivore. Beet armyworm triggered a priming pattern of activated defense genes and suppressed photosynthesis genes consistent with my predictions. However, cabbage loopers somehow avoided triggering this pattern. Offspring of primed plants also had altered chemical profiles. Finally, we confirmed herbivore-specific priming effects in field experiments. These discoveries indicate that plants do not employ a "one size fits all" approach in responding to volatile cues.

Broader Impacts: Plants display remarkable phenotypic plasticity and the idea that plants can detect and respond to (i.e., "smell") volatile cues routinely elicits considerable curiosity. I have leveraged this interest in an educational workshop called the "Million Leaf Project" (MLP), where participants learn to quantify herbivore damage on leaves and develop their own hypotheses related to this ecology. This grant allowed me to continue the MLP citizen science project, leading to a publication in the journal Ecology. The publication includes a "how to" supplemental section with details of the process for introducing citizen scientists to field measurements of herbivory. This is an important contribution with the potential to be incorporated into educational curriculum in a wide variety of settings because the tools and spreadsheets for real-time data entry and analysis are freely available. 

Additionally, this grant supported the completion of two PhD degrees, one M.S. degree, and two undergraduate honors theses. This grant enriched the training and professional development of seven female undergraduates, one female doctoral student, and one female postdoctoral researcher in the Frost lab, who collectively represented four religions and three nationalities. Moreover, this grant supported a first-generation female undergraduate student, who co-authored a publication and is now in medical school. This grant also fostered collaborative opportunities to test broader effects of volatile cues in nature. Finally, this project enabled 28 undergraduate and graduate students to learn the MLP technique by participating in the successful international field course I created preceding this grant. Several course participants used the MLP technique for their own independent projects and presented their results at scientific meetings. These participants and the thesis and independent study students trained on this grant are pursuing graduate or professional degrees.
